45.88.text:
This unusual model comes in a plain box
with Sarens on the front

49.69.text:
and it looks like inside there is
nothing but just a plain piece of foam

52.89.text:
but if we take that up there is still nothing
just a plain piece of

55.95.text:
foam, but we're not going to be put off
by that because if we lift out the pre-cut

60.71.text:
then the various parts of the model are seen all
carefully packed.

64.07.text:
There are no instructions for it though
which is a pity and on the review model

68.57.text:
One of the tie bars didn't have any
holes drilled in the end.

77.00.text:
This model is of a very unusual heavy
lifting frame

80.51.text:
and we start the assembly by building up
the tracks that it runs on.

83.76.text: There re six track sections - three for each side -

86.92.text:
and they are joined up by inserting a couple
of steel pins.

90.35.text:
They are quite small so it can be a little bit 
fiddly to get them in,

93.74.text:
particularly if you have got large fingers.
Anyway once they are joined up the track

98.67.text:
reasonably straight.  Here we've put one
of the four units on to the track and we are

102.77.text: going to extend up the lifting rams.

104.83.text:
They are multi stage and they are locked in place
by small grub screws

108.65.text:
and you use the supplied allen key to
unlock and lock them.

112.20.text: At first there seemed to be a problem on the review model in that some of the

116.59.text:
and couldn't be released.  But in fact
they were all released by putting some lateral

120.56.text: pressure on the allen key as you turn it.

122.45.text:
That seem to make the key grip the screw
better and that meant it could be

126.92.text:
We will now move on having set the height
of the rams to be the same

130.64.text:
on each of the units.  Two units go on
each track

134.22.text:
and to make them have the same distance
apart there is a tie bar

137.47.text:
and that drops into place over connecting
points on each of the units.

141.31.text:
If you then want to secure the tie bar
you can insert

144.44.text: a steel pin at each end, and here I've grown

147.46.text:
extra long metal fingernails to help get
the pin in.  But even so there's no

153.91.text:
and it is back to them to push the pin home
and to make sure the unit is properly

158.95.text:
Lastly we add on the lifting beams and
before we do that we add on a couple

164.46.text:
These just slide along the beam and they
are the main lifting points.

168.13.text:
The beam goes on the top of the rams and
it just sits there - it is not clipped

172.26.text:
on -  so it's best not to knock it or the
whole thing will collapse in a heap.

183.21.text:
Now we look at the detail on the various
parts and the tracks have a nice

186.59.text:
metal structure.  There are nice rubber
hydraulic hoses but they are delicate

190.82.text: so they will easily dislodge if you knock them.

192.86.text:
But on the plus side among the nice
touches are the small graphics

196.31.text:
and the painted control consoles.   At the
top of the units there are thin railings and replica

201.11.text:
lifting points, and the pistons are smooth
with hydraulic hoses running to each

205.81.text:
The lifting points and the beam are simple
enough and there are sharp graphics.

215.19.text:
One possibility for the model is to use
it as a transport load

219.22.text:
and of course it would look even better
with some trucks in Sarens colours.

222.53.text:
But let's assume it has all been delivered to
the work site and let's see how one of the

227.73.text:
Well underneath there are tiny little
metal rollers which turn

232.17.text:
and it is these which roll when you put the
unit on the track.

235.53.text:
On the model this all works quite nicely
with the unit rolling along pleasantly.

240.75.text:
The way it actually moves itself is to use
the hydraulic ram on the side.

245.09.text:
The end of it grabs hold of the centre
rail and then hydraulic ram is used to

251.22.text:
By repeating this the lifting frame is
able to move itself

254.51.text:
in a series of steps.   Anyway this is a
lifting frame so let it lift,

258.62.text:
let it lift, let it lift!  To do that you
need some straps which

262.57.text:
are not supplied with the model which is a
pity, but these ones are just be made out

267.60.text:
and the loops at the end are secured together
with some off cuts of a paper clip.

271.69.text:
Yes there's never any expense spared
at Cranes Etc!

275.29.text:
So here we have the straps attached, one
on each lifting point,

279.10.text:
and supplied with the model are some strap
guides which are to be placed

282.63.text:
under the thing to be lifted, and these are
nicely made metal parts and ar quite

287.30.text:
So now we need something to lift and
let's see what we can find...

300.91.text:
The real lifting frame is rated at 720
tonnes

304.53.text:
so this Tadano G6 crane is an easy lift
because it only weighs around 72 tonnes.

309.95.text:
To lift it up we are feeding the straps over
the partially extended

314.38.text:
outrigger beams and here you do have
to be quite careful how you apply the

319.25.text:
because if you get it unbalanced or apply any
lateral load at all

323.09.text:
it would all collapse in an impressive mess.
But with it all set up correctly it does

328.29.text: support the weight of the crane,

329.89.text:
and just to prove it we will move the crane
about a little bit

333.01.text:
to see that it is hanging free and
actually when it set up like this the

336.95.text: lifting frame does look very impressive.

349.41.text:
This is an interesting and unusual model
from YCC

352.97.text:
and this limited edition certainly does
look good in the colours of Sarens.

357.28.text:
It is a delicate model with some very nice
detailing

360.36.text:
and once you work through the issues of
setting it up

363.40.text:
then you get something which is actually
quite large. It is a nice looking model and
